iti76:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti76:2.1.pli: “Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, sukhāni patthayamāno sīlaṃ rakkheyya paṇḍito.
iti76:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, an astute person who wishes for three kinds of happiness should take care of their ethics.

iti76:2.3.pli: Pasaṃsā me āgacchatūti sīlaṃ rakkheyya paṇḍito, bhogā me uppajjantūti sīlaṃ rakkheyya paṇḍito, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissāmīti sīlaṃ rakkheyya paṇḍito.
iti76:2.3.eng: ‘May I be be praised!’ ‘May I become rich!’ ‘When my body breaks up, after death, may I be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’

iti76:2.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi sukhāni patthayamāno sīlaṃ rakkheyya paṇḍito”ti.
iti76:2.4.eng: An astute person who wishes for these three kinds of happiness should protect their precepts.”

iti76:3.3.eng: and to delight in heaven after passing away—

iti76:3.4.eng: the wise would take care of their ethics.

iti76:4.2.eng: if you associate with one who does,

iti76:5.1.eng: Whatever kind of friend you make,

iti76:5.4.eng: for so it is when you share your life.

iti76:6.1.eng: The one who associates and the one associated with,

iti76:6.2.eng: the one contacted and the one who contacts another,

iti76:6.3.eng: are like an arrow smeared with poison

iti76:7.2.eng: putrid fish in blades of grass

iti76:7.4.eng: so it is when associating with fools.

iti76:8.4.eng: so it is when associating with the attentive.

iti76:9.5.eng: The wicked lead you to hell,

iti76:9.6.eng: the good help you to a good place.”

iti76:10.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti76:10.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti77:2.1.pli: “Bhidurāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kāyo, viññāṇaṃ virāgadhammaṃ, sabbe upadhī aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā”ti.
iti77:2.1.eng: “This body is fragile, mendicants, consciousness is liable to fade away, and all attachments are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.”

iti77:3.2.comm: Virāgunaṁ is a secondary derivation from virāga with the -una suffix. Also found at MN 112:6.2.

iti77:3.3.eng: and seeing the danger in attachments,

iti77:3.4.eng: they go beyond birth and death.

iti77:4.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti78:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti78:2.1.pli: “Dhātuso, bhikkhave, sattā sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samenti.
iti78:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, sentient beings join together and converge because of an element:

iti78:2.2.pli: Hīnādhimuttikā sattā hīnādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samenti,
iti78:2.2.eng: Those who have inferior convictions join together and converge with those who have inferior convictions.

iti78:2.3.pli: kalyāṇādhimuttikā sattā kalyāṇādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samenti.
iti78:2.3.eng: Those who have good convictions join together and converge with those who have good convictions.

iti78:3.1.pli: Atītampi, bhikkhave, addhānaṃ dhātusova sattā sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandiṃsu samiṃsu.

iti78:3.2.pli: Hīnādhimuttikā sattā hīnādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandiṃsu samiṃsu,

iti78:3.3.pli: kalyāṇādhimuttikā sattā kalyāṇādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandiṃsu samiṃsu.

iti78:4.1.pli: Anāgatampi, bhikkhave, addhānaṃ dhātusova sattā sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandissanti samessanti.

iti78:4.2.pli: Hīnādhimuttikā sattā hīnādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandissanti samessanti,

iti78:4.3.pli: kalyāṇādhimuttikā sattā kalyāṇādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandissanti samessanti.

iti78:5.1.pli: Etarahipi, bhikkhave, paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ dhātusova sattā sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samenti.
iti78:5.1.eng: At present, too, sentient beings join together and converge because of an element.

iti78:5.2.pli: Hīnādhimuttikā sattā hīnādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samenti,
iti78:5.2.eng: Those who have inferior convictions join together and converge with those who have inferior convictions.

iti78:5.3.pli: kalyāṇādhimuttikā sattā kalyāṇādhimuttikehi sattehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanti samentī”ti.
iti78:5.3.eng: Those who have good convictions join together and converge with those who have good convictions.”

iti78:6.2.eng: they’re cut off by being aloof.

iti78:6.3.eng: If you’re lost in the middle of a great sea,

iti78:6.4.eng: and you clamber up on a little log, you’ll sink.

iti78:7.1.eng: So too, a person who lives well

iti78:7.2.eng: sinks by relying on a lazy person.

iti78:7.4.eng: a lazy person who lacks energy.

iti79:2.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
iti79:2.1.eng: “These three things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

iti79:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu kammārāmo hoti, kammarato, kammārāmatamanuyutto;
iti79:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant relishes work,

iti79:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
iti79:2.6.eng: These three things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

iti79:3.1.pli: Tayome, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattanti.
iti79:3.1.eng: These three things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

iti79:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu na kammārāmo hoti, na kammarato, na kammārāmatamanuyutto;
iti79:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t relish work,

iti79:3.4.pli: na bhassārāmo hoti, na bhassarato, na bhassārāmatamanuyutto;

iti79:3.5.pli: na niddārāmo hoti, na niddārato, na niddārāmatamanuyutto.

iti79:3.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
iti79:3.6.eng: These three things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

iti79:5.1.eng: That’s why one ought have few duties,

iti8:2.1.pli: “Mānaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
iti8:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding conceit, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

iti8:2.2.pli: Mānañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
iti8:2.2.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding conceit, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

iti8:3.1.eng: “These folk are caught up in conceit,

iti8:3.2.eng: tied by conceit, delighting in existence.

iti8:4.1.eng: Those who have given up conceit,

iti8:4.2.eng: freed with the ending of conceit,

iti8:4.3.eng: vanquishers of the tie of conceit,

iti8:5.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti8:5.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti80:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three unskillful thoughts.

iti80:2.3.pli: Anavaññattipaṭisaṃyutto vitakko, lābhasakkārasilokapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko, parānuddayatāpaṭisaṃyutto vitakko.
iti80:2.3.eng: The thought of status; of getting material things, honor, and popularity; and of fondness for others.

iti80:2.4.eng: These are the three unskillful thoughts.”

iti80:3.1.eng: “One concerned with being looked up to,

iti80:3.4.eng: is far from the ending of fetters.

iti80:4.1.eng: But one who gives up children and herds,

iti80:5.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti80:5.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti81:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti81:2.1.pli: “Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā sakkārena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā.
iti81:2.1.eng: “I’ve seen, mendicants, sentient beings whose minds are overcome and overwhelmed by honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

iti81:3.1.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā asakkārena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā.
iti81:3.1.eng: I’ve seen sentient beings whose minds are overcome and overwhelmed by not being honored. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

iti81:4.1.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā sakkārena ca asakkārena ca tadubhayena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā.
iti81:4.1.eng: I’ve seen sentient beings whose minds are overcome and overwhelmed by both honor and by not being honored. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

iti81:5.1.pli: Taṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nāññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā vadāmi;
iti81:5.1.eng: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin.

iti81:5.2.pli: (…) api ca, bhikkhave, yadeva me sāmaṃ ñātaṃ sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sāmaṃ viditaṃ tamevāhaṃ vadāmi.
iti81:5.2.eng: I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.”

iti81:6.1.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā sakkārena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā.

iti81:7.1.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā asakkārena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā.

iti81:8.1.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, sattā sakkārena ca asakkārena ca tadubhayena abhibhūtā, pariyādinnacittā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā”ti.

iti81:9.4.eng: as they abide in the immeasurables.

iti81:10.3.eng: Rejoicing in the ending of grasping,

iti81:10.4.eng: they’re said to be a true person.”

iti81:11.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti81:11.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti82:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti82:2.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, devesu devasaddā niccharanti samayā samayaṃ upādāya.
iti82:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three cries are uttered among the gods on occasion.

iti82:2.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya ceteti, tasmiṃ samaye devesu devasaddo niccharati:
iti82:2.3.eng: When a noble disciple shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, the gods cry out:

iti82:2.4.eng: ‘This noble disciple intends to join battle with Māra!’

iti82:2.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo devesu devasaddo niccharati samayā samayaṃ upādāya.
iti82:2.5.eng: This is the first occasion a cry is uttered among the gods.

iti82:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye ariyasāvako sattannaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanānuyogamanuyutto viharati, tasmiṃ samaye devesu devasaddo niccharati:
iti82:3.1.eng: Furthermore, when a noble disciple meditates pursuing the development of the seven qualities that lead to awakening, the gods cry out:

iti82:3.2.eng: ‘This noble disciple is joining battle with Māra!’

iti82:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo devesu devasaddo niccharati samayā samayaṃ upādāya.
iti82:3.3.eng: This is the second occasion a cry is uttered among the gods.

iti82:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye ariyasāvako āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, tasmiṃ samaye devesu devasaddo niccharati:
iti82:4.1.eng: Furthermore, when a noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, the gods cry out:

iti82:4.2.pli: ‘eso ariyasāvako vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasatī’ti.
iti82:4.2.eng: ‘This noble disciple has won victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle!’

iti82:4.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo devesu devasaddo niccharati samayā samayaṃ upādāya.
iti82:4.3.eng: This is the third occasion a cry is uttered among the gods.

iti82:4.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo devesu devasaddā niccharanti samayā samayaṃ upādāyā”ti.
iti82:4.4.eng: These are the three cries that are uttered among the gods on occasion.”

iti82:6.2.eng: You won a battle hard to win!

iti82:6.3.eng: Having defeated the army of death,

iti82:7.1.eng: And so the deities revere the one,

iti82:7.2.eng: who has achieved their heart’s desire.

iti82:7.3.eng: For they see nothing in them by means of which

iti82:7.4.eng: they might fall under the sway of Death.”

iti82:8.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti82:8.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti83:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti83:2.1.pli: “Yadā, bhikkhave, devo devakāyā cavanadhammo hoti, pañcassa pubbanimittāni pātubhavanti—
iti83:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a god is due to pass away from the realm of the gods, five warning signs appear.

iti83:2.2.pli: mālā milāyanti, vatthāni kilissanti, kacchehi sedā muccanti, kāye dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkamati, sake devo devāsane nābhiramatīti.
iti83:2.2.eng: Their flower-garlands wither; their clothes become soiled; they sweat from the armpits; their physical appearance deteriorates; and they no longer delight in their heavenly throne.
iti83:2.2.comm: Kāye dubbaṇṇiyaṁ okkamati doesn’t refer to the dimming of a divine radiance. It describes a declining physical appearance (AN 5.50:9.4).

iti83:2.3.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, devā ‘cavanadhammo ayaṃ devaputto’ti iti viditvā tīhi vācāhi anumodenti:
iti83:2.3.eng: When the other gods know that that godling is due to pass away, they wish them well in three ways:

iti83:2.4.eng: ‘Sir, may you go from here to a good place!

iti83:3.1.eng: When you have gone to a good place, may you be blessed with good fortune!

iti83:4.1.eng: When you have been blessed with good fortune, may you become well grounded!’”

iti83:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
iti83:5.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

iti83:5.2.eng: “Sir, what do the gods reckon to be going to a good place?

iti83:6.1.eng: What do they reckon to be blessed with good fortune?

iti83:7.1.eng: What do they reckon to become well grounded?”

iti83:8.1.eng: “It is human existence, mendicant, that the gods reckon to be going to a good place.

iti83:9.1.pli: Yaṃ manussabhūto samāno tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye saddhaṃ paṭilabhati;
iti83:9.1.eng: When a human being gains faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One,

iti83:9.2.eng: that is what the gods reckon to be blessed with good fortune.

iti83:10.1.pli: Sā kho panassa saddhā niviṭṭhā hoti mūlajātā patiṭṭhitā daḷhā asaṃhāriyā samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ;
iti83:10.1.eng: When that faith in the Realized One is settled, rooted, and planted deep; when it’s strong and can’t be shifted by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world,

iti83:10.2.eng: that is what the gods reckon to become well grounded.”

iti83:12.2.eng: a god passes from the realm of the gods,

iti83:13.1.eng: ‘Go, worthy sir, from here to a good place,

iti83:13.3.eng: As a human being, gain supreme faith

iti83:14.1.eng: May that faith of yours be settled,

iti83:14.4.eng: in the true teaching so well proclaimed.

iti83:17.1.eng: then, having made much worldly merit

iti83:17.4.eng: in the true teaching, the spiritual life.’

iti83:18.1.eng: It is due to such sympathy

iti83:18.2.eng: that when the gods know a god

iti83:18.3.eng: is due to pass away, they wish them well:

iti83:19.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti83:19.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
